review_title: Small, very bright, versatile and a snap to charge
reviews:
I was looking for a second EDC flashlight and I decided to go for the S1R II because I was impressed with the size and performance of my S1 Mini.

Reading about the improvements made to the S1R model with the S1R II made me decide to spend a bit of extra money for this new model and here is why I’m happy I did.

So clearly the new flashlight is brighter than the mini version. Charging the S1R II is so much more practical than the S1 Mini. No need to open up the flashlight to remove the battery for charging. The magnetic charging adaptor just snaps in place and begins charging.

The tail-cap of the S1R II has a stronger magnet as well, this holds the flashlight in place with more tenacity when securing to a metal surface.

The one negative I found about my older S1 Mini is that the light spot created is not perfectly even, it has a hotspot because of the way the S1 Mini lens is frosted. In the attached picture you can see that the S1R II does not have this frosting ont he lens and the spot it creates is a bit tighter, brighter and more even than the S1 Mini.

Finally the only downside to the S1R II in comparison to the S1 Mini is it’s run time. Considering that it has a higher lumen output, 1000 to 600, and also a slightly smaller capacity battery, 550 mAh compared to 650 mAh, it cannot keep up with the S1 Mini. It does make up for this however. During operation the power button glows either Green, Orange, or Red to warn user of battery capacity so that you can charge it when needed, It also easy to setup the charge with the magnetic adaptor but more importantly it charges much quicker, more than twice the rate of charge of the mini.

Neither of these EDC flashlights are ideal as your only light source on a prolonged activity in the dark, but as an occasional flashlight they are just perfect. If for some reason you are in a bind and need to use it for a prolonged period just reduce the light output to a lower setting to get a longer run time.

The S1R II is an easy choice for a every day carry flashlight that is small, yet very bright, versatile and a snap to charge.

In the attached pictures the S1R II is to the left and S1 Mini is to the right.

I've recently purchased the S2R II and have compared it with this model for those interested. It's larger than this one, but has massive run time in comparison.

review_title: Great upgrade from original S1R...Ideal EDC or keychain light....
reviews:
Overall, tons of significant upgrades add up to a great second generation pocket light.

The original S1R Baton in my opinion has always been something of a milestone for flashlights. CR123A with built in recharge and 900 lumens in a tiny package you could put on your keychain.

The 2nd generation, S1R II is significantly improved. It's smaller (~3.5 mm shorter) lighter, (-4 grams) , brighter (+100 lumens) with a more powerful magnet on the base and has more aggressive knurling on the body. The 2-way pocket clip allows you to easily convert a baseball cap into a headlight, but is now a truly 2-way clip. The pocket clip is updated so it won't rotate on the body. The S1R II still works with regular RCR123A batteries and lithium primary cells CR123A).

I tested it with a light meter (Comparative bounce off white ceiling in basement) and the turbo definitely put out enough light to be 1000 lumens. As most turbo modes, this one is short lived. You get about 90 seconds before it steps down to 300 lumens. Similarly, the 600 lumen high setting steps down after 90 seconds also. It then gives you 300 lumens for about 45 minutes. With a new CR123A, it won't hold high and steps down to the 60 lumen after a fraction of a second. Still, 60 lumens isn't bad for something this size running from primary (non-rechargeable) batteries.

A significant change is that they have added a raised ring on the Olight battery between the positive and negative terminals - it's still possible, but much less likely that a bare battery will short out. Performance with non-Olight Lithium-ions is similar, but you won't get the built in charging without the proprietary Olight battery. One affect of this however is that you cannot recharge this battery unless you use the flashlight - or get yourself a small magnet to serve as a positive button extension (See picture).

I keep mine mechanically locked out. While you can lock out the smart switch by pressing and holding until the moonlight goes out, I prefer to simply unscrew by 1/2 a turn since the threads are anodized.

reviews:
I have sold flashlights myself a few years back - I still have a few of the (then American made) models. I sold them to raise money for cancer research. Since then, the company that manufactured them sold off their consumer flashlights to a Chinese company and now only makes their more expensive torches aimed at the military and law enforcement markets here in the US.
Those flashlights - the models I sold - I later found out were commonly used by submariners (my son was in the Navy when I was selling them). They were far less expensive than the Surefire lights that some of the officers used but served the enlisted guys equally well. Very well made and virtually indestructible. And had the same water resistance as this little (VERY little) Olight S1R II.
But to compare the performance of those older lights with today's brighter and more efficient LEDs would be an "apple to oranges" thing... However, what you get for the money is a very different story.
This Olight flashlight is just SO MUCH MORE value dollar for dollar (like most tech gadgets - "Moore's Law" ??

Those older (2013-2014) lights I sold were at a minimum 3 times the size (for a relatively weak light) and larger for maybe 150 lumens or so. And with only one brightness setting, and not useable with rechargeable batteries at all.
This Olight has 3 regular modes, plus the "moon" mode and the "turbo" mode....and also the very bright "strobe" mode.
There were, of course, other flashlights at that time that could be "programmed" but nothing as easily (to my knowledge) as this new S1R II light. I tried a few and found them to be generally difficult and/or awkward to get used to.This Olight is amazingly easy to use (got mine and it took just a few minutes to understand and even remember the simplicity of changing modes and locking out the control button. (The lockout is an especially useful function - even the timer is very simple - choice of either 3 minutes or 9 minutes for auto shut-off in any mode). It also can instantly go from any lower power to "turbo" or to strobe with 2 or 3 quick presses respectively.
The wide "hot spot" makes this light more useful for me. I didn't need a ton of "throw" for my specific uses. I do have a rechargeable flashlight with a very narrow and exceptionally long throw with1600 lumens, but while it has it's uses, it's not as practical for me in most instances - and definitely won't fit in any pockets. It's probably around 20x times the size overall, (and guessing that much heavier also) and more than 5 times longer than this tiny Olight. (and that 1600 lumen light is NOT waterproof).
I have a few Maglights (large D cell "battering ram" weight) My mom kept one on her nightstand as a weapon - must be lethal in the hands of a 90-year-old woman awakened in her bed by an armed intruder? LOL.

This tiny Olight seems to be a great alternative to both other pocket-size EDC lights as well as the much larger flashlights.
This light will be on my person for EDC for the foreseeable future.
Also, I think the magnetic external charger is great! Can be used virtually anywhere - home, car, boat, etc. And the light itself having a magnetic tail can be a terrific convenience as well...stick it where you want it (on a ferric based surface) and no need to hold in with your teeth to free your two hands :)
All in all, an easy 5 stars all around!!!

This will be long winded.
I waited 5 months to review this light. It has been an awesome light and I couldnt be happier.

I've carried tiny lights that are ok for some things and I keep a large light in all my vehicles. But I wanted a light i could carry at all times that could do it all. Light up an engine bay, look under the fridge, or light up the night and blind a potential attacker. I watched a bunch of YouTube videos and the one by IV8888 sold me.

Everything I had worried about turned out to be no big deal at all. I worried about the magnetic base trying to grab everything and collecting bits of steel while welding/grinding/ect. Very very little of that happens. Sometimes it will collect in the lanyard hole but a burst from and air nozzle takes care of it. It is actually quite awesome sticking it to a car part to light up whatever you are working on.

I worried about it being heavy and not fitting in my pocket well enough for every day carry comfort. I dont even notice it is there.

I worried about the pocket clip not working well enough to keep it securely in my pocket. Biking, working, running, nothing worries me. It fits very well in my pocket beside my knife. That is my EDC for my right front pants pocket. The light kind of shifts to the side and sits perfectly so it doesnt dig into my thigh at all. (See pics)Minor wear from my pocket on the button and minor wear from rubbing against whatever Kershaw I'm carrying.

I worried about the different settings being a pain in the bum to deal with but that's not the case because of the memory. Push it once and it's at the last setting you used. Double press and bam theres a yard full of light. Triple press and it's a blinding strobe. Long press and it's the lowest setting that lasts for days

Overall 5 stars easy. Lasts longer than I expected on the 2nd brightest setting which is what I use 95% of the time. But when I need to knock it up another notch BAM its there and i dont have to worry about it dying in 4 minutes.

Just buy it
